extracted_information: This study explores user perceptions, usage patterns, and associations with health outcomes for the religious mobile app, Pray.com, based on a survey of 1031 USA subscribers. It provides insights into why users engage with the app, how they use it, and the self-reported benefits they experience.

features.name: Daily Prayer
features.description: Most widely used content, strongly associated with improvements across various health and well-being domains.

features.name: Bible in a Year
features.description: Popular content, associated with improvements in mental health, anxiety, spiritual well-being, relationship with God, prayer life, and meaning/purpose in life.

features.name: Bible Stories
features.description: Popular content, associated with improvements in stress, sleep, anxiety, spiritual well-being, relationship with God, prayer life, and meaning/purpose in life.

features.name: Meditative Prayers
features.notes: More likely used by Black or African American respondents.

features.name: Daily Prayer reminders
features.description: Feature used to encourage regular app usage.

features.name: Pray.com community
features.description: In-app community feature with low utilization, despite ~33% of users having friends who also use the app.

features.name: Reading the Bible
features.notes: More likely used by Black or African American respondents.

length_of_use.one_to_two_years: White respondents more likely than Black/African American respondents
length_of_use.two_or_more_years: Black/African American respondents more likely than White respondents

impact_of_usage_frequency_on_improvement.dosage_effect_observed: Greater use related to increased self-reported improvement
impact_of_usage_frequency_on_improvement.no_significant_relation: Frequency of use not related to improvements in depression and burnout.
